description: Maize, also known as corn, is a tall annual cereal grass that yields large grains, or kernels, set in rows on a cob. It is one of the most widely cultivated cereal crops in the world, used for human consumption, animal feed, and various industrial products.
seasons: Typically planted in spring and harvested in late summer or fall, depending on the climate and variety.
healthBenefits: Good source of fiber, aiding digestion and promoting gut health.
Contains antioxidants like lutein and zeaxanthin, beneficial for eye health.
Whole grain corn can be part of a heart-healthy diet.

potentialAllergies.name: Corn Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: An allergic reaction to proteins in corn. Symptoms can range from skin rashes and digestive issues to anaphylaxis in rare cases. Corn derivatives are common in processed foods, which can make avoidance challenging for allergic individuals.

cultivationProcess: Maize cultivation involves preparing a well-tilled seedbed, planting seeds after the last frost, ensuring adequate nitrogen fertilization, managing weeds and pests, and harvesting when kernels are mature (dent stage for grain, milk stage for sweet corn).
growthDuration: Typically 60-100 days for sweet corn, and 90-120 days for field corn, depending on variety and climate.
sustainabilityTips: Conservation tillage or no-till farming to reduce soil erosion.
Cover cropping to improve soil health and reduce nutrient runoff.
Integrated pest management (IPM) to minimize pesticide use.
Water-efficient irrigation methods where irrigation is necessary.
carbonFootprintInfo: The carbon footprint of maize varies depending on farming practices, particularly nitrogen fertilizer use (which can lead to nitrous oxide emissions). Ethanol production from corn also has associated carbon costs.

staticRecipes.name: Simple Boiled/Steamed Corn on the Cob
ingredients: Fresh corn on the cob, husks and silk removed
instructions: For Boiling: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add the corn cobs. Cook for 5-7 minutes, or until kernels are tender. Drain.
For Steaming: Place a steamer basket in a pot with about an inch of water. Bring to a boil. Place corn cobs in the basket, cover, and steam for 7-10 minutes, or until tender.
Serve hot with butter, salt, and pepper if desired.
staticRecipes.notes: Do not add salt to the water when boiling corn, as it can toughen the kernels. Cooking time may vary depending on the freshness and type of corn.

staticRecipes.name: Basic Skillet Cornbread
ingredients: 1/4 cup vegetable oil or melted butter
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease a 9-inch cast-iron skillet or an 8x8 inch baking pan.
In a large bowl, whisk together cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In a separate bowl, whisk together milk, oil/butter, and egg.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir until just combined (do not overmix).
Pour batter into the prepared skillet or pan.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until golden brown and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
Let cool slightly before slicing and serving. Best served warm.
staticRecipes.notes: For a crispier crust, preheat the greased cast-iron skillet in the oven before adding the batter.

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Corn Salsa
ingredients: 2 cups fresh corn kernels (from about 3-4 ears of corn, can be raw or lightly blanched/grilled)
1 jalapeño, minced (seeds removed for less heat, optional)
instructions: If using raw corn, you can use it as is for a crunchy salsa. Alternatively, blanch the corn kernels in boiling water for 2-3 minutes or grill the cobs until lightly charred, then cut off the kernels.
In a medium bowl, combine corn kernels, diced red onion, diced red bell pepper, minced jalapeño (if using), and chopped cilantro.
In a small bowl, whisk together lime juice and olive oil.
Pour the dressing over the corn mixture and toss to combine.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Let the salsa sit for at least 10-15 minutes before serving to allow the flavors to meld. Serve with tortilla chips or as a topping for grilled chicken or fish.
staticRecipes.notes: Feel free to add other ingredients like black beans, diced avocado, or chopped tomatoes. Adjust lime juice and jalapeño to your preference.

originAndDomesticationHistory: Maize was domesticated from a wild grass called teosinte (Zea mays ssp. parviglumis) in southern Mexico between 7,000 and 10,000 years ago. Early cobs were very small. Through selective breeding by indigenous peoples, maize evolved into the diverse forms known today and spread throughout the Americas. It was introduced to Europe by Columbus and subsequently spread globally.

climaticRequirements.temperature: Optimal daytime temperature 20-30°C; sensitive to frost.
climaticRequirements.rainfall: 500-1000mm during the growing season, or irrigation. Requires good moisture during tasseling and silking.
climaticRequirements.altitude: Can be grown from sea level to over 3000m, but most commercial production is in lowland and mid-altitude regions.

soilPreferences: Prefers deep, well-drained, fertile loamy soils with good organic matter content. Optimal pH range is 5.8-7.0. Requires high nutrient availability, especially nitrogen.
irrigationAndWaterNeeds: Water needs are critical during germination, tasseling, silking, and early grain fill stages. While it can be rain-fed, supplemental irrigation is common in many regions to ensure optimal yields, especially in drier climates.
plantingAndHarvestCycles: Planted in spring when soil temperatures reach 10-13°C. Seeds are typically sown 4-5 cm deep. Harvest for sweet corn is when kernels are in the 'milk stage'. For grain corn, harvest is done when kernels are dented and dry, typically using combine harvesters.
pestAndDiseaseManagement: Common pests include corn earworm, fall armyworm, corn borers, and rootworms. Diseases include northern corn leaf blight, gray leaf spot, and Stewart's wilt. IPM strategies involve resistant hybrids, crop rotation, biological controls, and chemical control when necessary.
postHarvestHandling: For grain corn, it involves drying the kernels to 13-15% moisture content for safe storage, cleaning, and storing in bins or silos protected from pests and moisture. Sweet corn is highly perishable and needs immediate cooling and marketing or processing (canning, freezing).
marketValueAndGlobalDemand: Maize is a globally significant commodity with high demand for animal feed, ethanol production, and human food products (cornmeal, cornstarch, corn syrup). Its market value is influenced by global supply, demand, weather, and energy policies.
